awd_titl_txt: Targeted Infusion Project: Infusion of Cyber Physical System Education and Research Training in the Undergraduate Curriculum in the College of Engineering at TSU
awd_abstract_narration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) through Targeted Infusion Projects supports the development, implementation, and study of evidence-based innovative models and approaches for improving the preparation and success of HBCU undergraduate students so that they may pursue science, technology, engineering or mathematics (STEM) graduate programs and/or careers. The project at Tennessee State University will enhance undergraduate education by establishing an interdisciplinary Cyber-Physical System (CPS) program and prepare students to meet the needs of the workforce or advanced studies in CPS related fields.  

The CPS program spans the departments of computer science and electrical and computer engineering. The project will develop a state-of-the-art Cyber Physical System Research and Education Laboratory that will provide opportunities for research, education, and outreach in CPS for students and faculty; and incorporate learning modules into the programs at the undergraduate level to meet the needs of the technology workforce and impart essential knowledge and skills to prepare a competitive workforce in CPS. In developing such a program, the project will adopt, in contrast to the commonly used 'bottom-up' learning approach, a 'top-down' reverse-engineering paradigm for imparting knowledge that would seek to orient students with the paradigm of a CPS from an early stage with students gradually gaining detailed understanding of its building blocks both from a theoretical and practical perspective.  The project will provide important insights into the effectiveness of the top-down approach.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project has been to develop an interdisciplinary undergraduate Cyber-Physical System (CPS) Program in the College of Engineering (CoE) at Tennessee State University (TSU). In developing such a program, the project has employed, in contrast to the commonly used 'bottom-up' learning approach, a 'top-down' reverse-engineering paradigm for imparting knowledge that seeks to orient students with the concept of a CPS from an early stage at a macroscopic level with students gradually gaining detailed understanding of its building blocks from theoretical and practical perspectives. Such a 'top-down' learning approach has resulted in the enhancement of student recruitment, learning, motivation, and engagement, has enabled the preparation of a competitive workforce for CPSs, as well as has facilitated imparting knowledge in areas that go beyond the realms of a CPS. Aligned with such a learning approach, the project has led to the development of complementary undergraduate concentrations, particularly one on Cyber Physical Systems and another on Cyber-Security and Networking, in the CoE at TSU. This has had a positive impact on the development of a skilled workforce for fueling the engineering of next-generation technologies. Further, infusion of CPS curriculum into engineering programs has led to the integration of research and educational activities catalyzing interdisciplinary interactions among faculty, students, and researchers, fostering research and development activities in many important areas related to CPSs, and enhancing the research capacity of TSU.

The project has had a significant impact on the development of human resources. The developed learning modules have been infused into courses at TSU enhancing knowledge and skills of diverse students, including underrepresented groups, and their recruitment and retention in STEM. The developed concentrations in the CoE have been designed to meet the needs of the technology workforce and prepare a skilled workforce for CPS. Further, the project, via integration of research and educational activities, has exposed diverse populations to recent scientific and technological innovations and provided them with new opportunities for pursuing research and developmental activities. The results obtained in the project have led to several publications and presentations.


Last Modified: 06/20/2024
Modified by: Swastik Brahma
